definition: Inoculating is transferring bacteria from solution onto growth media, usually by a small streaking loop.
gloss: Inoculating adds bacteria to broth to help them grow.

definition: Diluting is adding more growth media to an initial culture
Inducing is adding a certain reagent to trigger protein production in a culture
Pelleting is running a centrifuge to separate bacteria from a culture
Suspending is adding a liquid, usually to a bacterial pellet, for long term storage.
Aliquoting is splitting a large amount of liquid into many smaller containers.
Lyophilizing is like freeze-drying, and is used to preserve bacteria & enyzmes.

Like PCR, makes lots of DNA copies from single fragments. Instead of denaturing (peeling DNA into two strands) beforehand, LAMP (and other isothermal amplification methods) uses a polymerase that simply displaces DNA as it goes. Because you don't have to heat the DNA, it can be done at a constant temperature. Also, it's more prolific. ((Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification) uses 6-8 primers vs PCR using 2, resulting in an exponentially higher yield)
